entry.title: Re: Factory Calendar Special Rules - CDS View or API
entry.content:
Hello @GAK1 

Thank you for your question.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, no released CDS View or API directly exposes Factory Calendar → Special Rules date from-to, workday flag, text. These are reflected internally in the working-day pattern but not as a dataset.

You can instead use the following released views and approach:

CDS View I_FACTORYCALENDAR – provides factory calendar IDs, validity, and descriptions.

CDS View I_FACTORYCALWorkingDaysPerYr – returns encoded working-day patterns per year/month, which already consider any special rules.

Join this data with I_CalendarDate to derive a daily IsWorkingDay indicator if you need day-level results.

If external access is required, build a Custom CDS View on top of these released views and expose it as an OData API through a custom communication scenario.

In the public cloud, traditional tables like TFAIN/TFAIT and transactions used in on-premises systems are unavailable.
Check  SAP Help Portal – Factory Calendar in S/4HANA Cloud and the Released VDM Views documentation for I_FACTORYCALENDAR

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Bank Statement not completed
entry.content:
Hello @panagiotism 

Thank you for your question.

In your case and based on your description, I think what is happening is when you import a bank statement, the posting logic uses Posting Area 1 for the main bank entry and Posting Area 2 for clearing open item. Which is consistent with the public cloud.

If Vendor open item is already cleared as is in your case, the system still expects Area 2 to find and clear an open item. Therefore, the statement remains Not Completed because the clearing logic cannot find a match.

In public cloud, you cannot modify the posting rules or disable Posting Area 2 due to the clean core restrictions SAP introduced in that edition.

In public cloud edition, you cannot skip Posting Area 2 in the posting rule but you can make the bank statement complete by ensuring that:

  • The external transaction type used in the bank account master matches one that is configured without an open-item clearing requirement, or
  • The system recognises the item as external transaction completed through reconciliation processing. This will ensure that Posting Area 2 is automatically marked as complete.

To summarise:

Posting Rule F010 expects you to have an open item for Posting Area 2, but your item was already cleard.

The restrictions in public cloud hinder some modifications due to Clean Core approach.

Your solution options are:

  1. To create a Processing Rule to mark as completed when no open items exists.
  2. Or manually mark statement as completed in Manage Bank Statements.
  3. For future automation, ensure your external transaction mapping in Manage Bank Accounts are correct.

The following references provide more details.

Manage Bank Statements

Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing

Manage Processing Rules for Bank Statements

Cash and Liquidity Management

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Limitation in Service Quotation Handling in SAP S/4HA...
entry.content:
Hello @Lasse96 ,

You’ve run into current design limits of Service Quotation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition:

SAP’s FAQ states you can’t delete an accepted service quotation due to a follow-up service order. The app also doesn’t allow deletions of open quotations, so the standard way to undo is to reject them, optionally letting it expire. SAP Community-Service Quotation in S/4Hana Service - Frequently Asked Questions

Sold-To Party change: For Service Quotations in Public Cloud, the Sold-To is not changeable after creation. Attempts to modify partner changeability through SSCUIs result in the same partner-procedure error you indicated; SAP considers this expected behavior.

Copy as template: Use Reference works, but keep original partner determination, suitable only for the same Sold-To. For a different customer, SAP recommends rejecting the incorrect one and creating a new quotation for the correct Sold-To. (See: rejection handling and  learning content.) SAP Learning-Explaining the Service Quotation Process Steps

Useful SAP Documentation

  • Microlearning: Using Rejection Reasons in Service Quotations and Orders. SAP Learning
  • FAQ (Service Quotation): Deletion/acceptance behaviour and recommended handling. SAP Community
  • KBA 3324390: Sold-To is not editable when copying if partner procedure flags it non-changeable. SAP Support Portal
  • Partner determination (help/overview): Background on how partner changeability is controlled by procedure. SAP Help Portal

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Manage Landed Costs / Additional Costs Functionality...
entry.content:
Hi @cblikeem 

Thank you for your question.

There is no Manage Landed Costs Fiori app in public cloud edition. That name appears in on-prem/private cloud discussions, it isn’t a standard public cloud app today.

However, if standard clean core is adhered to, you can capture freight, customs, insurance, etc. When set up correctly, you can capitalise them into inventory value through standard delivery costs in Purchasing and Invoicing:

  • Planned delivery costs on the PO à Posted to a delivery-cost clearing account at GR/IV and distributed to the material when the supplier/freight invoices are posted.
  • Unplanned delivery costs on the supplier invoice à can be distributed to PO items so that inventory value is adjusted (This is subject to valuation settings).
  • Multiple vendors are supported by using separate invoices that settle the delivery-cost clearing.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Delivery Costs (Planned and Unplanned)

Create Supplier Invoice with Purchase Order

Direct Procurement, Reconcile GR/IR Accounts: Business Background

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Why Is the Test Execution on my Test Plan remain 0% a...
entry.content:
Hello @oquijano0327 

This behaviour usually happens when the automated process runs without a bound Test Data Container (TDC) variant or without valid test-user authentication. The Executed: “Without Test Data Conta...” message in your log confirms that the test launched without an active data variant, so no steps could execute

Please check the following points

Ensure a TDC variant is bound and used. Add the TDC to the test process or plan, and select the variant as the default. If a run begins “without TDC,” steps will not be parameterised, and you will see “Executed: Without Test Data Container.” SAP Help-Test Your Progress-Add Test Data Container to Test Plan

Validate test user, login to Manage Test User. Plans stuck at 0% commonly trace to wrong or stale credentials for the test user. Re-enter a known-good password (or switch to SSO) and re-run. SAP Support Portal-2820953 - Automatic test processes start, but no progress

If you use an external IdP. You should configure Conditional Authentication in Test Your Processes; otherwise, runs stay at 0%. SAP Help Portal-Configure Test Your Processes

Authorisations, ensure admin/tester has SAP_BR_ADMIN_TEST_AUTOMATION from Maintain Business Roles; without it, key TAT functions are blocked. SAP Support Portal-3111932 - Missing role SAP_BR_ADMIN_TEST_AUTOMATION in Maintain Business Role app

In 'Manage Your Test Processes', open 4HH automate and confirm each step has an Automated Script (some tenants/plans miss synced content, so nothing runs). Refresh content and re-add the process if needed. SAP Help Portal-About the Application

General stuck at 0%” troubleshooting, SAP KBAs list these exact symptoms and recommend re-checking credentials, roles, and rerunning after fixing settings. SAP Support Portal-3087418 - Test Plan execution is not progressing or stuck at 0%

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Error connecting interfaces with FACe (Spain)
entry.content:
Hello @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thank you for sharing the details and screenshot.

The XML is valid as FACe accepts it when uploaded manually, so the issue lies in the connection, trust, or authorisation between SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite, and Face. The server error points to a communication problem in the iFlow, not content mapping.

The Spain FACe content is provided as an SAP Integration Suite package named “SAP Document and Reporting Compliance: Electronic Invoicing of Public Entities for Spain.” You need to copy, configure, and deploy its iFlows (Send/Status/Cancel) SAP API Hub/SAP Document and Reporting Compliance: Electronic Invoicing of Public Entities for Spain

Find the concrete setup PDFs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub, which include step-by-step instructions for copying the package, setting endpoints, and security material. SAP API Hub

Pinpoint errors in Integration Suite Monitor → Message Processing. This is the primary place to see the exact HTTP/TLS/auth failure that produced the CXF {faultcode}server symptom. SAP Help Portal/SAP Integration Suite/Monitor Message Processing

Certificate/trust issues (PKIX path) are a common cause of CXF “server” faults. SAP’s notes and community guidance confirm that missing/incorrect root or intermediate certificates in the tenant keystore lead to PKIX/handshake failures. SAP Support Portal/2874258 - Error "sun.security.validator.ValidatorException: PKIX path building failed" occurs testing the connection of a SOAP web service datastore - SAP Cloud Platform Integration for Data Services

S/4HANA Cloud side: validate the Communication Arrangement that points to your Integration Suite runtime and use the Connectivity Trace if needed (handy for SSL handshake/login problems). SAP Help Portal/Communication Arrangements

Product area reference: Spain electronic documents under Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC). SAP Help Portal-Spain-Document and Reporting Compliance

Your initial diagnosis is correct: because FACe accepts your XML files when uploaded manually, the issue probably resides in the transport connection (endpoint, authentication, or certificates) between S/4HANA Cloud and Face through the Integration Suite. Use the Message Processing monitor to pinpoint the specific error, then modify the endpoint, credentials, or keystore trust chain according to the Spain package guide.

Let me know if you need further assistance

Chuma

GenAI-Assisted Content (sources: SAP Help & SAP Business Accelerator Hub).

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order -Order confirmation Interface Failing
entry.content:
Good day @Rkmandal 

The issue you are facing isn’t with configuration or authorization but with locking and sequencing. You cannot change cloud locking behaviour (Clean Core) but you can prevent the conflict through CPI message serialisation or delayed retries.

In summary, when you send Order Confirmations from a 3rd-party system to public cloud through SAP CPI, you may get the user Inbound error. This happens because the same user used in the communication arrangement is still locking the purchase order while another message tries to update it. That means:

  • Two confirmations arriving at the same time for the same PO
  • CPI retries too quickly before the previous message is finished

Although you can’t change the locking logic in public cloud, you can solve it from the CPI side by:

  1. Configuring your iFlow to process messages one after another per PO number
  2. Adding a short 15-30 second delay in the exception flow before CPI retries.
  3. Splitting integration load by using different technical users if you process many Pos in parallel.

Here are references for more information.

User already processing the purchasing document "XXX"

Purchase Order Confirmations

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Request for validation of S/4HANA Data Migration Stra...
entry.content:
Good day @S0026934150 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, your overall Data Migration Strategy is well-structured and closely aligned with SAP’s recommended approach for phases S/4HANA rollouts. Below are a few validation points and best-practice confirmations for key areas you raised.

1. You are making use of SAP BODS for your ETL. This is validated and also recommended because that is the preferred ETL tool for complex S4/HANA migration programs, especially when you have high-volume master and transactional data, you need data profiling and enrichments capabilities, you need traceability and auditability across production loads, etc.

  • Best practices are combining the migration cockpit with SAP Advanced Data Migration or SAP Data Service for target uploads.
  • Ensure your BODS-to-S/4 integration ends with standardized load templates.

 2. The use of Master Data Synchronisation between ECC and S/4HANA is partially recommended. Rather use selective synchronisation. Make sure you avoid continuous, full bi-directional synchronisation. Instead maintain controlled synchronisation for master data that are shared across rollouts.

  • SAP recommends using SAP MDG or central data governance layer for harmonisation rather than one-off technical interfaces.
  • If MDG is not yet in place, restrict synchronisation to read-only reference replication through IDocs or API to prevent dual maintenance errors.

 3. Implementing MDG is considered best practice, especially if you have a multi-entity rollouts. It ensures: Central governance and approval workflow for master data creation, A reliable record for each master data object across geographies & Provides consistency and reduce deduplication effort in later load cycles.

  • Use MDG for key domains like Business Partner, Material Master, and Finance Master Data.
  • Integrate MDG output directly with S/4HANA through SOA services or IDoc replication to ensure synchronisation integrity.

 4. Qualification and Validation for Mock and Production Loads are compliant with the SAP methodology. Your plan to conduct at least two mock load cycles is consistent with SAP’s Activate and Data Migration Factory standards.

  • The final production load must have full traceability.
  • For high-volume domains, ensure incremental data load testing to avoid performance bottlenecks.

 5. Overall strategy aligns well, however, consider the following aspects:

  • Consider integration SAP Data Intelligence for metadata management and lineage tracking, especially if multiple sources exist.
  • Introduce a Central Data Migration Factory approach for cross-region large rollouts.
  • Document data ownership, sign-off workflows, and cutover sequencing in your final plan to align with the Quality Gate framework.

 

Consult these references for more details.

SAP Activate Methodology Workstreams Names update

Data Migration

SAP Master Data Governance

Handling Data Migration Content

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Managing Large Investment Projects with SAP Investment Management
entry.content:
Large investment projects are complex and resource-intensive. They require careful planning, budgeting, monitoring, and control to ensure successful execution. These projects play a vital role in a company’s growth, financial stability, and operational efficiency. To manage them effectively, organizations need a structured and integrated digital solution.

SAP Investment Management (IM) provides a comprehensive framework to manage capital investments efficiently. The module integrates seamlessly with other SAP components such as Project System (PS) and Asset Accounting (AA), enabling end-to-end visibility and control over capital expenditures.

This blog highlights a three-part series of papers that together explain the full capabilities of the SAP Investment Management module:

  • Part 1 – Configuration of the Investment Program and Appropriation Requests (Requesting Measures)
  • Part 2 – Setup of Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) and the Settlement Process
  • Part 3 – Step-by-step execution process for managing large-scale capital investments

By combining insights from all three papers, this blog serves as a complete guide to SAP Investment Management, offering practical knowledge for finance, project management, and SAP professionals seeking to improve how they plan and control large investment projects.

INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT IN SAP: A KEY TOOL FOR MANAGING LARGE EXPENDITURES

Investment Management (IM) is a key module in SAP that helps organizations plan, monitor, and control major spending initiatives. These expenditures can be capital-related, such as investments in infrastructure, machinery, or technology, or non-capital, including R&D, acquisitions, or major maintenance projects.

The IM module allows companies to design their own investment program structure based on business needs, consolidating all approved and planned costs into a hierarchical framework. Using requesting measures, such as Appropriation Requests, organizations can plan long-term investments that often span several years in line with project lifecycles.

SAP IM also incorporates workflow-based approvals, ensuring strong governance and compliance throughout the investment process. While IM focuses on planning and budgeting, effective investment lifecycle management also requires linking it with Investment Measures, the operational side of managing project costs and asset creation.

Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) in SAP are the objects that receive budgets, track planned versus actual costs, and settle expenses to fixed assets, cost centers, or general ledger (G/L) accounts. Depending on the investment type, these measures may take the form of WBS (Work Breakdown Structure) elements or internal orders.

In essence, SAP Investment Management brings together four key components, which work seamlessly to ensure accurate, transparent, and efficient management of capital and non-capital investments. The following section explores these components in more detail.

STEPS IN MANAGING LARGE EXPENDITURES IN SAP INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT

Fig 1: SAP Investment Management Overview

Source: SAP Help Portal on Investment Management (Overview) 

  1. Requesting Measures (Appropriation Request): Similar to a purchase requisition, an appropriation request is used to request approval for large expenditures. This request contains critical details about the project, including the planned costs. A standard SAP workflow is set up to ensure that appropriation requests are reviewed and approved before any funds are committed.
  2. Investment Program: The investment program provides a hierarchical structure within the organization to plan, budget, and distribute large expenditures. The program allows the organization to define its own structure based on needs. All approved planned costs for requesting measures are aggregated within this hierarchy. Costs are planned from the bottom up, while budgets are allocated from the top down. Investment measures can only be assigned to the lowest level in the hierarchy, called "end nodes," which can include internal orders, WBS elements, or maintenance orders.
  3. Investment Measure: Investment measures are used to track the planned budget and actual spend. These can be Project System (WBS) elements or Internal Orders. Investment measures receive the budget allocated from the investment program and track the actual expenditure as it occurs. It tightly controls the spending by monitoring the planning, budgeting, actual, commitment, and remaining available funds. Investment measures are closely linked with the Asset Accounting module in SAP, ensuring that any unallocated spending at period-end is properly settled into assets under construction (AUC).
  4. Settlement planning and settlement: Once a project or investment measure is completed or partially completed, it must be settled. A project can be settled to various objects, such as fixed assets, cost centers, other investment measures, or general ledger accounts. The settlement process requires careful planning to determine how funds will be allocated (e.g., by percentage, amount, or proportion). Once the project is ready to settle, the settlement rules are defined in the investment measure to transfer the financial information to the appropriate accounts..

The whole design of implementing and end-to-end execution investment management in SAP is divided into 3 papers as below. These papers are free to download and use:

Paper 1: Laying the Foundation: Structuring Investment Programs and Approval Request— A Guide to Initiating and Organizing Capital Investments

This paper covers the initial steps in managing large projects through SAP Investment Management, including the setting up of investment programs and the process for requesting measures. The paper can be downloaded from the link below:

 Part 1 – Configuration of the Investment Program and Appropriation Requests (Requesting Measures)

 Paper 2: From Planning to Action: Configuring Investment Measures and Settlement Processes — Ensuring Control and Accountability in Capital Projects

This paper focuses on configuring investment measures and defining settlement rules, providing the foundation for effective planning, tracking, and accountability in capital project execution. The paper can be downloaded from the link below:

Part 2 – Setup of Investment Measures (WBS or Internal order) and the Settlement Process

Paper 3: Executing Large Investments: A Step-by-Step Guide to Project Delivery and Oversight— Managing the Full Lifecycle of Strategic Expenditures

The final paper outlines the end-to-end execution process for managing large-scale investments using SAP, including project tracking, monitoring, and lifecycle management. The complete end-to-end Investment Management execution process in SAP includes the following five key steps:

  1. Establishing the Investment Program Structure.
  2. Initiating Investment Plans through Appropriation Requests.
  3. Building Project System Hierarchy.
  4. Cost Planning and Budgeting.
  5. Executing and Settling the Project.

The paper can be downloaded from the link below: 

Part 3 – Step-by-step execution process for managing large-scale capital investments

Conclusion

Effectively managing large capital investments is vital for an organization’s financial health and long-term success. In this three-part series on SAP’s Investment Management (IM) paper, we’ve presented a complete framework for planning, executing, and settling large-scale expenditures in a structured and efficient way.

  • Paper 1 laid the foundation by configuring investment programs and requesting measures, establishing a clear structure for tracking planned spending.
  • Paper 2 focused on designing investment measures and settlement rules, enabling organizations to monitor and control project execution throughout the investment lifecycle.
  • Paper 3 demonstrates the end-to-end execution process of large capital projects, from master data setup to project execution and final settlement.

By following this integrated approach, organizations can confidently manage investments, keeping projects on budget, meeting deadlines, and aligning with strategic objectives. SAP’s IM module helps navigate the complexities of capital investment management, optimizing financial operations and supporting both short-term and long-term business goals.

Together, these three papers provide a step-by-step guide to managing strategic investments, giving businesses the clarity, control, and insight needed to ensure success in their capital projects.

entry.title: Re: SAC Numeric Point - How to show last year same day value
entry.content:
@N1kh1l 

Thank you so much for your reply—your input has really sparked some new ideas, and I’m truly grateful for that!

But if you don’t mind, I still have a few more questions to ask. I know I can use LOOKUP([Sales], [d/Date] = Previous("Year", 1)), but it seems to return the total for the entire previous year rather than breaking it down to the daily level. Since I need to see the figures for each specific day, I haven’t gone with this "previous year" method.

Also, when I count back 365 or 366 days to map LP/NLP values, I can’t just rely on the year alone to do it simply. Take 2024 and 2025 as an example: for any date on or before February 28, 2025, I need to subtract 366 days to get the corresponding value from the previous year. But for dates after March 1, 2025, I have to subtract 365 days instead—otherwise, the value from February 29, 2024, would end up incorrectly mapped to March 1, 2025.   So in a scenario like this, do I have to add some month-specific conditions to the IF statement to perfectly align the LP and NLP values? This approach feels a bit cumbersome, and I’m curious if there’s a more efficient way to handle it.

entry.title: Carbon Management: Mastering GHG Scope 3.1 Emissions with SAP Sustainability Solutions
entry.content:
Disclaimer: Information in this blog post is targeted for users with a license of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management & SAP Sustainability Control Tower. It reflects the state of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management & SAP Sustainability Control Tower as of September 1st, 2025.

Are you ready to transform your organization's carbon management journey?
As part of our Q3 Sustainability Adoption Efforts,  @loic_maquinghen and I launched a webinar series tailored for both customers and partners. Our goal was to empower you with the confidence to embark on your organization's sustainability journey using SAP sustainability solutions, and to demonstrate how these tools can unlock immediate value through insightful use-case demonstrations.

To ensure you have everything you need to kickstart your corporate carbon management journey, we’ve published an end-to-end implementation guide. This guide is packed with step-by-step guidance and pre-filled templates, enabling you to dive right into the setup and utilization of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower for carbon management & accounting.
With this you are fully equipped to implement a minimum viable scope for corporate carbon management within just 3 business days!
Specifically you will learn how to do the setup, calculation and reporting of carbon emissions with the help of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower.

Whether you're currently utilizing SAP Sustainability solutions or planning its implementation, these resources are designed for YOU. They are your first stepping stone in driving real, meaningful change in your organization’s carbon management efforts.
Click on the linked resources below to find out more. 

 

 DescriptionCustomerPartner
Webinar Recording (1h)Expert-led webinar to initiate your path to sustainability with SAP - unlocking immediate value through a detailed case study demonstration. LinkLink
Implementation GuideStep-by-Step Implementation Guide (incl. pre-filled templates) to setup SAP Sustainability Footprint Management & SAP Sustainability Control Tower to calculate GHG scope 3.1 emissions of an example company and manage this metric for further CSRD reporting.LinkLink

To put it in a nutshell, with the resources from this article and your licensed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management & SAP Sustainability Control Tower solution, you can start right away and try a carbon case study in a guided do-it-yourself approach - implementing a minimum viable scope in your own system within 3 business days. The idea with these resources is to enable you to do a quick and easy system setup, data maintenance and carbon calculation as a first building block to start carbon management within your organization. 
We are curious how it works for you. Please do let us know here in the comments.

entry.title: Vibe Coding a Mobile App to display Business Partners
entry.content:
Last week I posted about the release of the MCP server for mobile development kit. In that post, I’ve provided details about the setup and offered some simple use cases as examples. In this post, I will be using the Cursor coding agent together with the MCP server for mobile development kit to vibe code a mobile app from scratch.

We are going to create a simple mobile app that shows a list of Business Partners. The sample data is stored in an S/4HANA Cloud instance made available through SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

It is important to note that while Cursor is featured in this example, SAP is evaluating several coding agents to ensure broad compatibility with our MCP server. This demonstration does not imply preference or endorsement of any particular product.

Picking a data source from SAP Business Accelerator Hub

We start with opening SAP Business Accelerator Hub and browsing to the Business Partner API overview. This is an API available on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Editor. We are going to use this API for our mobile app. To set up the connection in SAP Mobile Services, we need to gather some information.

Select Show API Key and copy the key.

In the Configuration Details tab, you will find the SANDBOX URL. Copy this URL.

Configuring the mobile app in the SAP Mobile Services Admin cockpit

Assuming you have an instance of SAP Mobile Services available in your SAP BTP subaccount, open the Mobile Services Admin cockpit.  You can do this via Service Marketplace, select Mobile Services and open the Support link. There is no need to create an instance here.

If you don’t have the service yet, simply add the Mobile Services entitlement to your subaccount. If you’ve created a brand-new subaccount, then make sure to enable Cloud Foundry, add the Cloud Foundry Runtime entitlement and allocate some runtime memory (1 unit is sufficient). You will also need an active Cloud Foundry space.

In the Mobile Services Admin cockpit, navigate to the Mobile Applications > Native/MDK tab and click New. Select Mobile Development Kit (MDK) as the type of application. Click Next.

Provide details about the app.

Click Next and leave the remaining configuration steps unchanged. Select Finish after reviewing the selections.

Once the app definition is created, select Connectivity.

We will now set up a connection to the data service we’ve found in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. We first provide information about the Destination Name and Destination Type (Internet Destination).

For the URL, paste the URL you’ve copied from SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Click Next.

Create a custom header called apikey and paste the API key you’ve obtained from Business Accelerator Hub into the Header Value field.

For the remaining steps, leave all settings as default and click Next and finally Finish.

Access your Cloud Foundry environment

To be able to exchange information between your (local) development environment and your SAP Mobile Services instance, you need to log in to your BTP environment on Cloud Foundry. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

The easiest way to log in is to use the following command and follow the instructions to open the provided url:

cf  login <your target endpoint> --sso

Your target endpoint is visible on the Overview page of your BTP subaccount.

 

Using Cursor

Configuring the coding agent

We’ll open Cursor, where we have configured the mdk-mcp server. Detailed instructions can be found at https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/mdk-mcp-server . For Cursor, you'll find the MCP servers in the Cursor Settings > Tools & MCP. You can enable or disable MCP servers as needed. My recommendation is to only enable those MCP servers that are needed to perform a specific tasks. Having too many tools active could confuse the agent and LLM.

Retrieving the mobile application details

For our project, we need to collect information about the mobile app definition and mobile destination we've created earlier. Go to the Command Palette and open “MDK: Open Mobile Application Editor”

 

The Mobile Application editor opens. Select the application we’ve created in SAP Mobile Services and tick the box of the destination.

By clicking “Add App to Project”, we collect all relevant information into a file named “.service.metadata”. This information will be used to create the mobile application project in the next steps.

Let’s get mobile vibe coding!

We are now ready to start creating the mobile application. We type the following prompt in the agent’s chat pane:

Create a mobile application to browse the list of Business Partners. 
Besides updating the generated README.md file, do not create documentation.
Make sure there are no linting errors and validate the project.

Note: I’ve specifically mentioned to skip creating documentation. This is because this agent, combined with Claude Sonnet 4.5, is very keen on creating documentation. Although this is a good practice, it can cause issues with bundling our metadata. There is also no need to ‘burn’ more tokens than necessary.

After a few iterations, the application and README.md file has been created.

To test what has been generated so far, we will deploy the application to SAP Mobile Services.

Open a new chat and enter the prompt

Deploy the application

Based on the information retrieved from the MCP server, the agent will trigger a deployment to SAP Mobile Services and show a QR code that we can use for onboarding the SAP Mobile Services client application. This client can be downloaded from the App Store and Google Play.

 

The mobile app looks like this on iPhone:

 

The app runs fine. However, the partner list shows mainly record id numbers. We also notice this number get repeated in the list. Can we change this without touching any of the code or metadata? You don’t need to be an MDK expert to enhance the app. Your agent can help!

We use the following prompts:

Change the Business Partners list to show their name and search term 
instead of business partner id and customer id.
Change the subhead to BusinessPartnerGrouping.
On the list page, change the title to “Business Partner Overview”

The main page also looks like we are pulling the information straight out of a database. Let’s fix that.

On the main page, change the title to My Business Partners, 
change the "vibe_coded_demoapp" text to "Vibe coding showcase", 
change "A_BusinessPartner" to "Show list of Business Partners"

The level of detail on the page varies based on the agent and LLM; sometimes it's very detailed, while smarter agents produce more compact pages. In my example, there's too much information for mobile viewing.

To make the detail page more compact, please remove the 
relationship sections (to_<name>) and reduce the visible fields.
On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details"

The object header on the detail page could look a bit better if we change the contents.
 

On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details" 
and in the object header, please show the following items: 

headline = full name
subhead = id
BodyText = organization name
footnote = search item
Description = form of address
Status text = is blocked
substatus text = category

After the agent makes the changes, the resulting app is deployed and looks a bit a better:

 

We can ask the agent to review the app and make it look even better. For this use case, I’ve provided screenshots of the main page, the list page and the detail page and prompted:

Can you make the main/list/detail page look more professional

After several iterations, and reminding the agent to consult the MDK documentation, we have an app the indeed looks better. For the main page, I’ve also asked to add an image with the SAP logo.


Short summary of the changes made for each page:

  • Main page
    • Added branding footer toolbar
    • Added logo image
    • Improved button design
    • Added welcome section
    • Added brief key features overview
  • List page
    • Circular avatars
    • Blue accent color
    • Improved search bar
  • Detail page
    • Cleaner object header
    • Split the long list into logical sections
    • Improved layout
    • Better visual hierarchy

 

Thoughts

For those unfamiliar with MDK and the tools we provide, it might look like magic to create a mobile app like this one. However, before the arrival of coding agents we already offered generators that offered scaffolding. The AI coding agent makes use of the same tools to create the app. What has changed is that instead of the developer continuing to enhance the project manually, it is now the coding assistant doing most of these changes based on the prompts provided by the developer.

In some cases, I’ve noticed the agent makes wrong assumptions and does not consult the information made available through the MCP server. An example of this is regarding the CSS styling. The agent assumed full support for CSS styling, like available in modern HTML5-based web apps. However, MDK offers limited support for styling. Without checking the documentation, the agent created styles that had no effect. I had to remind the agent to check the documentation first (maybe we should create a rule for this).

Practical recommendation: It is better to start every task in a separate chat with your agent to keep the context window small. This will help creating better results and less hallucinations.

Conclusion

Developing a mobile app based on Mobile Development Kit is now faster and easier thanks to AI coding agents. By introducing the MCP server for mobile development kit, we ensure coding agents can tap into knowledge and best practices that LLMs have not been trained on (yet).

Depending on the coding agent and LLM used, your results may vary. The development still needs supervision. Always review what the coding agent produces and make adjustments where needed.

As always, feedback is welcome.

entry.title: The Case of the underpaid/overpaid Wage Type: A Analyzing Guide for Consultants
entry.content:
Introduction:  In SAP HCM Payroll, consultants often face situations where employees are unexpectedly underpaid or overpaid due to wage type discrepancies. These issues can arise from retroactive changes, incorrect master data entries, or schema misconfigurations.

This blog outlines a structured approach to analyze such cases using the RAW trace tools—Results Table, Audit Report, Wage Type Reporter—and PCR (Personal Calculation Rule) trace. For example, if wage type 7013 is missing or altered, this guide helps pinpoint whether it's due to retroactive master data changes or schema logic.

In this blog, I'll walk you through go-to process for analyzing missing wage types using the RAW & PCR Trace:

Results table(PC_PAYRESULT)

Audit Report(SE38 -> RPUAUD00)

Wage type reporter (PC00_M99_CWTR)

PCR: Personal Calculation Rule

1.) The First Step: Verifying the Master Data:

  -> Check the info type where the wage type is entered (e.g., 0014, 0015, 2010).

  -> Ensure it's valid for the payroll period.

2.) Enabling the RAW (Results table, Audit Report, Wage type reporter) Trace:

  -> Results table: check RT _ for the WT, check "In period" and  "for period" if the WT having the Retro.

  ->  Check the Audit report (SE38-> RPUAUD00) for any retro changes, previous values for the info types records

  -> Check the Wage type reporter (PC00_M99_CWTR) for Retro values and Wage type splits:

3.) Analyzing the PCR (Personal Calculation Rule) Trace:

  -> If RAW Trance not found not any deviations, check the PCR flow Trace, open the payroll log for the employee and try searching with the Wage type code (example: 7013), and check the amount where it is getting reduced and open the line for the PCR.

4.) Common Culprits: Why Wage Types Disappear based on PCR's:

   -> Incorrect Processing Class settings (e.g., 1- Evaluation, 2-Cumulation).

   -> A PCR with an ELIMI operation.

   -> The wage type is not included in the relevant schema.

   -> A decision in the schema that branches away from your wage type.

Conclusion: By following the RAW trace and PCR analysis steps, consultants can efficiently identify the root cause of wage type discrepancies and resolve them before they impact payroll accuracy. Whether it's a missing wage type due to an ELIMI operation in a PCR or a retroactive change not reflected in the results table, this guide equips you with the tools to investigate systematically.

For instance, checking SE38 → RPUAUD00 can reveal retro changes that explain unexpected payroll results. With these techniques, you can turn payroll day surprises into confident resolutions. Have you encountered a tricky wage type issue? Share your experience in the comments!

entry.title: SAP UI5 application to Export Data to spreadsheet from SAP UI5 tree table (sap.ui.table.TreeTable)
entry.content:
Introduction : 
    In this article, we are going to understand how to implement  export functionality the sap.ui.table.TreeTable table data to the excel(Spreadsheet) using  sap.ui.export.Spreadsheet library. In this application, we are going to create an SAP UI5 free style application which has sample JSON  data  that has employees and their family details for the expense share percentage of the medical insurance (taken as an example) and that has been binded to the UI table and a toggle button has been added to trigger the export or downloading the excel data.

Procedure: 
This is step by step guide to create a fiori application with SAP UI5 UI table and Export Button
Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the  Fiori Generator Freestyle - Basic template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

 

 

 

Application Folder Structure: 

 

 

Step 2 : Create a Dynamic Page , add UI Table Details and Add the sample JSON Data in controller 

  In TreeTableView.view.xml, Add this code and add the Sample JSON data model object in the onInit() in TreeTableView.Controller.js .

TreeTableView.view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.example.treeexporttoexcel.controller.TreeTableView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:table="sap.ui.table"
>
    <Page
        id="page"
        title="{i18n>title}"
    >
        <content>
            <table:TreeTable
                id="employeeTreeTable"
                selectionMode="None"
                enableColumnReordering="false"
                rows="{ 
       path : '/Employees',
       parameters :{
       arrayNames:['Employees','FamilyMembers']
       }
        }"
            >
               <table:extension>
                 <OverflowToolbar>
                        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
                        <ToolbarSpacer />
                        <ToggleButton id="export_btn" text="{i18n>export_btn}" icon="sap-icon://excel-attachment" press="onExcelExport"/>
                    </OverflowToolbar>
               </table:extension>     
                <table:columns>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>employeeID}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{EmployeeID}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>employeeName}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{EmployeeName}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>designation}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Designation} " />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>familyMemberName}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{MemberName}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>relation}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Relationship}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>age}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Age}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>expense}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{ExpenseShare}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                </table:columns>
            </table:TreeTable>
        </content>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

TreeTable.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet"
], (Controller, JSONModel, MessageToast, Spreadsheet) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.example.treeexporttoexcel.controller.TreeTableView", {
        onInit() {
            var oView = this.getOwnerComponent();
            var oDataModel = new JSONModel();
            var aData = {
                "Employees": [
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E001",
                        "EmployeeName": "Ramesh",
                        "Designation": "Manager",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Anitha",
                                "Age": 35,
                                "Relationship": "Wife",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Rohith",
                                "Age": 10,
                                "Relationship": "Son",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Ramanaiah",
                                "Age": 65,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Kamala",
                                "Age": 60,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            }
                        ]
                    },
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E002",
                        "EmployeeName": "Sumana",
                        "Designation": "Developer",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Bhargav",
                                "Age": 35,
                                "Relationship": "Husband",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Prasanna",
                                "Age": 9,
                                "Relationship": "Daughter",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Ananda",
                                "Age": 58,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Srinidhi",
                                "Age": 55,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            }
                        ]
                    },
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E003",
                        "EmployeeName": "Manish",
                        "Designation": "Auditor",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Bhumesh",
                                "Age": 58,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 60
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Rajeswari",
                                "Age": 50,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            }
                        ]
                    }

                ]
            }

            oDataModel.setData(aData);
            oView.setModel(oDataModel);
        },
}); 
});

Step 3 : Implement the press event trigger of the Export To excel Button
   Add this logic in controller.js . "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library should be used for excel export.
_convertTreeForExport() is a recursive function to fetch the child records converts to flat structure and pushes to the export data where this export data is passed to the settings of the excel sheet data.
TableView.controller.js

 onExcelExport() {
            var oBundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("i18n").getResourceBundle();
            var oTable = this.byId("employeeTreeTable");
            var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("rows");
            var aData = oBinding.getModel().getProperty("/Employees");
            var aExportData = this._convertTreeForExport(aData);
            var aCols = [
                {
                    label : oBundle.getText("employeeID"),
                    property :"EmployeeID"
                },
                {
                     label : oBundle.getText("employeeName"),
                    property :"EmployeeName"

                },
                {
                      label : oBundle.getText("designation"),
                    property :"Designation"
                },
                {
                       label :oBundle.getText("familyMemberName"),
                    property :"MemberName"

                },
                {

                       label : oBundle.getText("relation"),
                    property :"Relationship"
                },
                  {

                       label : oBundle.getText("age"),
                    property :"Age"
                }, {

                       label :  oBundle.getText("expense"),
                    property :"ExpenseShare"
                }
            ]
            var oSettings = {
                workbook: {
                    columns: aCols,
                    context: {
                        sheetName: oBundle.getText("sheetName")
                    }
                },
                dataSource: aExportData,
                fileName: oBundle.getText("fileName"),
                worker: false
            };
            var oSpreadsheet = new Spreadsheet(oSettings);
            oSpreadsheet.build().then(function () {
                MessageToast.show(oBundle.getText("successMessage"));
            }).finally(function () {
                oSpreadsheet.destroy();
            })
        },
          
        _convertTreeForExport(aNodes, iLevel =0, aResult =[]){
// aNodes will have the tree table  data 
// iLevel -> current hierarchy depth initializes with 0
// aResult -> collector array of the flattened data 
            aNodes.forEach(oNode => {
                // taking shallow copy of each node to perform manipulations on the copy node without  // disturbing the actual data node
                   var oCopy = { ...oNode };
// deleting FamilyMembers nested structure to avoid recursion loops if not deleted it will throw  // the maximum call stack exceeded error
                delete oCopy.FamilyMembers;
                oCopy.level = iLevel + 1;
// creates a new field for visualize indentation  parent, child, grandchild etc., 
                oCopy.IndentedName = `${"".repeat(iLevel*4)}${oNode.name}`
                aResult.push(oCopy);
                if(oNode.FamilyMembers && oNode.FamilyMembers.length > 0){
                    this._convertTreeForExport(oNode.FamilyMembers, iLevel + 1, aResult);
                }
            });
               return aResult
        }

Application Screen:

 

 

ExportData.xlsx

 

 

Git Link for reference
https://github.com/RangarajasreeSV/tree-table-export-to-excel-ui5

Conclusion: 
By following these steps, We can achieve the export functionality of the The SAP UI tree table data to the Excel spreadsheet.


Thanks and Regards,
Sree Vedavyasa Rangarajasree

entry.title: Master Data Sync in Public Dimension using Hybrid Stories and Scripting in SAC
entry.content:
Introduction

Maintaining data consistency across two dimensions' attributes depending on the ID or any other attribute is a common need in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

For instance, if one dimension (let's call it A Dimension) contains master data like product color, size, or type and another dimension (let's call it B Dimension) depends on it, then changes to a property in A Dimension must automatically be reflected in B Dimension.

Under these circumstances:

Dimension A = Dimension of the Product

B Dimension Equals Group Dimension

The objective of this approach is to use a reference key (Default_Product_ID, for instance) to synchronize the values of attributes (such Color_Code and Size_Label) between these two dimensions.

Using SAC scripting, this blog demonstrates how to synchronize properties between two dimensions in hybrid stories.

Overview of the Use case

ConceptDescription
Model UsedProduct_G_Model
Dimensions InvolvedProduct Dimension and Group Dimension
Key RelationshipEach Group member contains a property called Default_Product_ID that links it to a Product Dimension ID field
Purpose

Copy Color_Code and Size_Label from Product Dimension to Group Dimension for members flagged as “Y”

Steps involved in implementation

Step 1: Select the Planning Model

  • Choose the Planning Model.
  • Select Product_G_Model, the planning model that includes both public dimensions.

Step 2:  In the script, declare global variables.

Under Script Variables, create the following variables:

Variable NameTypeModeDescription
GroupMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Group members 
ProductMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Product members 
Update_PRD_KPINumberSingle
 

Tracks count of updated members

These variables make the script easier to read and reuse.

Steps 3: Write a Script Function

Create a function under Script Objects:

  • Name: updateGroupFromProducts
  • Return Type: PlanningModelMember[]
  • Arguments:
    • ProductMembers: PlanningModelMember[]
    • GroupMembers: PlanningModelMember[]

Based on Product data, this method will include the logic to change Group properties.

Step 4:  Write the Script Logic

The actual SAC script that does the synchronization is shown below:

var updatedMembers = ArrayUtils.create(Type.PlanningModelMember);
for (var j = 0; j < GroupMembers.length; j++) {
	var Member = GroupMembers[j];
	if (Member.properties.Flag === "Y") {
		for (var i = 0; i < ProductMembers.length; i++) {
			if (ProductMembers[i].id === Member.properties.Default_Product_ID) {
				Member.properties.Color_Code = ProductMembers[i].properties.Color_Code;
                Member.properties.Size_Label = ProductMembers[i].properties.Size_Label;
                updatedMembers.push(Member);
                break;
			}
		}
	}
}
return updatedMembers;

Step 5: Execute on Initialization

The script used to get members, apply updates, and refresh the model during the app's initialization is shown below:

GroupMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("Group_Dimension_P1",{limit:2000});
ProductMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("PRD_DIM_2L",{limit:200000});
 var updList=ScriptObject_1.updateGroupFromProducts(ProductMembers,GroupMembers);
	Update_PRD_KPI=updList.length;
        if (updList.length > 0) {
            var success = Product_G_Model.updateMembers("Group_Dimension_P1", updList);
            if (success) {
                Application.refreshData();
            }
        }

Sample Output

After execution, Group members flagged as "Y" will have their Color_Code and Size_Label updated based on the linked Product member.

Benefits

  • By automatically synchronizing the master data, automation removes the need for manual updates.
  • Consistently Keeps dependent dimensions conformed.
  • Reusability Function-based design allows the same logic to be applied to multiple dimensions.
  • The simplicity deploy the features and methods that are currently included in SAC scripting.

Conclusion

This method ensures data synchronization between two related dimensions within a SAC Planning Model.

Changes to dimension properties are managed while maintaining data consistency.

entry.title: Building a Lightweight Fiori-Style System Monitor with Node.js
entry.content:
Introduction

A small, lightweight tile that tells you how your server’s doing right now.  A compact Node.js app that fetches system metrics and presents them with a clean, Fiori-style interface.

To recreate this setup, you will require: 

Accounts & Platforms

  • SAP BTP Free Tier account 
  • GitHub (optional) – If you want to version your code or YAML files.

Local Tools

  • Shell or Terminal – Any terminal works (Mac Terminal, Windows PowerShell, WSL, etc.).
  • Visual Studio Code (VSC) – For editing the JS code and YAML files (not strictly necessary, but a nice to have!)

1. Setup the project

mkdir sendstats
cd sendstats
npm init -y 
npm install express

2. Create server.js

// Import modules from Node’s standard library
import express from "express";
import os from "os";
import { exec } from "child_process";

const app = express();
const PORT = process.env.PORT || 3000;

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Serve static files from the "public" folder
// This means index.html and any JS/CSS/images in there will be delivered
// directly when requested by the browser.
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.use(express.static("public"));

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// GET /stats
// This endpoint gathers system statistics (CPU, memory, uptime, disk usage)
// and returns them as JSON when the frontend calls fetch("/stats").
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.get("/stats", (req, res) => {
  // Run the shell command "df -h" to get human-readable disk usage
  exec("df -h", (err, stdout) => {
    // If the command failed, store an error message; otherwise, trim whitespace
    const dfOutput = err ? "Error running df" : stdout.trim();

    // Get memory information from Node’s os module
    const memTotal = os.totalmem();
    const memFree = os.freemem();
    const memUsedMb = (memTotal - memFree) / 1024 / 1024;

    // Build a data object containing all metrics we want to send to the client
    const data = {
      uptime: os.uptime(),                    // seconds since system start
      load: os.loadavg(),                     // 1-, 5-, and 15-minute load averages
      memUsedMb,                              // used memory (MB)
      memTotalMb: memTotal / 1024 / 1024,     // total memory (MB)
      memPct: ((memUsedMb / (memTotal / 1024 / 1024)) * 100).toFixed(1), // %
      cores: os.cpus().length,                // number of CPU cores
      dfOutput,                               // result of "df -h"
      timestamp: new Date().toLocaleString(), // when we collected it
    };

    // Send the JSON response back to the browser
    res.json(data);
  });
});

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Start the Express web server
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log("Fiori-style monitor running at http://localhost:" + PORT);
});

So, this is now serving /stats to a front-end HTML tile that will display uptime, memory, load averages, and disk usage. 

That endpoint returns a tidy JSON snapshot, perfect for a front-end fetch call.

3. The HTML front-end

From the root of the project:

mkdir public

The folder structure (up to now) should look like this:

sendstats/

├── server.js

├── package.json

└── public/

    └── index.html

    └── script.js

Here’s the finished index.html with a working toggle switch that hides or shows the entire tile:

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />
    <title>System Tile</title>
    <style>
      body {
        font-family: "72","Segoe UI",sans-serif;
        background: #f4f4f4;
        display: flex;
        justify-content: center;
        align-items: center;
        height: 100vh;
        margin: 0;
        flex-direction: column;
      }
      .tile {
        background: white;
        border-radius: 1rem;
        box-shadow: 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
        padding: 1.5rem 2rem;
        width: 340px;
        text-align: left;
        transition: opacity 0.3s ease, transform 0.3s ease;
      }
      h1 {
        font-size: 1.2rem;
        color: #0a6ed1;
        margin-bottom: 0.75rem;
      }
      pre {
        font-family: monospace;
        font-size: 0.9rem;
        background: #fafafa;
        padding: 0.75rem;
        border-radius: 0.5rem;
        overflow: auto;
      }
      .footer {
        text-align: center;
        margin-top: 0.75rem;
        font-size: 0.8rem;
        color: #6a6d70;
      }
      button {
        background: #0a6ed1;
        color: white;
        border: none;
        border-radius: 0.5rem;
        padding: 0.5rem 1rem;
        cursor: pointer;
        margin-bottom: 0.5rem;
      }
      button:hover {
        background: #085caf;
      }
      .switch-container {
        display: flex;
        align-items: center;
        margin-bottom: 1rem;
      }
      .switch {
        position: relative;
        display: inline-block;
        width: 46px;
        height: 24px;
        margin-right: 0.5rem;
      }
      .switch input {
        opacity: 0;
        width: 0;
        height: 0;
      }
      .slider {
        position: absolute;
        cursor: pointer;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        right: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        background-color: #ccc;
        border-radius: 24px;
        transition: 0.3s;
      }
      .slider:before {
        position: absolute;
        content: "";
        height: 18px;
        width: 18px;
        left: 3px;
        bottom: 3px;
        background-color: white;
        border-radius: 50%;
        transition: 0.3s;
      }
      input:checked + .slider {
        background-color: #0a6ed1;
      }
      input:checked + .slider:before {
        transform: translateX(22px);
      }
      #toggleLabel {
        font-size: 0.8rem;
        color: #6a6d70;
      }
      .hidden {
        opacity: 0;
        transform: scale(0.95);
        pointer-events: none;
      }
    </style>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div class="switch-container">
      <label class="switch">
        <input type="checkbox" id="toggleTile" checked />
        <span class="slider"></span>
      </label>
      <span id="toggleLabel">Tile: ON</span>
    </div>

    <div class="tile" id="tile">
      <h1>System Monitor</h1>
      <button id="refresh">Refresh</button>
      <pre id="output">Loading...</pre>
      <div class="footer" id="footer"></div>
    </div>

    <script src="script.js"></script>
  </body>
</html>

4. The JavaScript logic

The script.js code below handles fetching the stats and toggling the tile’s visibility:

// script.js
async function fetchStats() {
  const res = await fetch("/stats");
  const d = await res.json();
  document.getElementById("output").textContent =
`Uptime: ${(d.uptime / 60).toFixed(2)} min
Loadavg: [${d.load.map(n => n.toFixed(2)).join(", ")}]
Memory: ${d.memUsedMb.toFixed(0)} MB / ${d.memTotalMb.toFixed(0)} MB (${d.memPct}%)
CPU cores: ${d.cores}

Disk usage (df -h):
${d.dfOutput}`;
  document.getElementById("footer").textContent =
    "Snapshot generated on " + d.timestamp;
}

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
  const refreshBtn = document.getElementById("refresh");
  const tile = document.getElementById("tile");
  const toggle = document.getElementById("toggleTile");
  const label = document.getElementById("toggleLabel");

  refreshBtn.addEventListener("click", fetchStats);
  fetchStats();

  toggle.addEventListener("change", (e) => {
    const visible = e.target.checked;
    label.textContent = visible ? "Tile: ON" : "Tile: OFF";
    tile.classList.toggle("hidden", !visible);
  });
});
node server

Now, when you load up localhost:3000, you should see something like this: 

You can toggle the tile on an off with the slider button: 

Off: 

5. Deploy it the Cloud Foundry

Create a manifest.yml under the root of the directory, so that the directory structure now looks like this:

sendstats/

├── server.js

├── package.json

├── manifest.yml

└── public/

    └── index.html

    └── script.js

Your manifest.yml should look something like this:

---
applications:
  - name: sendstats
    memory: 128M
    random-route: true
    command: npm start

Deploy to the Cloud Foundry with 'cf push':

cf push sendstats

You should see the following in your workspace after the app has started up: 

Click on the app name and it should take you to the 'Application Route' shown below: 

Click on the link and you should see the app: 

6. Result

When you load the app:

  • The system tile appears in the centre, showing uptime, load average, memory, CPU cores and filesystem usage.
  • The “Tile: ON/OFF” switch above it cleanly hides or shows the card with a subtle fade.
  • Everything stays minimal, modern, and in line with SAP’s Fiori look and feel.
  • You get a 'Refresh' button, which is nice!

Conclusion

This 10 minute project shows how far you can go with a few lines of JavaScript By combining a lightweight Node.js backend with a Fiori-inspired front end, we built a self-contained system monitor that’s simple, responsive, and useful.

The toggle feature gives it that final touch of polish — a reminder that usability doesn’t have to come from massive frameworks or libraries. Sometimes it’s just a matter of a few smart UI details and clean logic.

entry.title: Launch your Data Science Platform with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's set the architecture.

Within SAP Business Data Cloud we will use SAP Datasphere and SAP Business Data Cloud. Note that SAP Databricks runs on its own Object Store. This is not the same object store that could be activated in SAP Datasphere. We will not activate an Object Store (BDC Object Store) for this case.  You can do that. This means, that you will benefit from Data Products (SAP and Customer managed). But as of today you will lose semantics. Therefore we will go for another approach this time. Make sure to check which approach might be best for you.

 

  • 1. Step: Activate SAP Datasphere and SAP Databricks. If you already have a Datasphere (activated before 2025) and you want it to be in your BDC formation, please make sure to contact your BDC account executive.
  • 2. Step: Within SAP Datasphere create a space (HANA Cloud not Hana Data Lake Files)
  • 3. Step: Within this space, create a view which is exposed for consumption. Note that you have to create a view. Tables (also remote tables) cannot be exposed

  • 4. Step: Create a database user 

  • 5. Step Open SAP Databricks
  • 6. Step Open a Workbook and connect it to a running Cluster 
  • 7. Step Insert the following to find your Clusters IP Address
%pip install fedml-databricks --no-cache-dir --upgrade --force-reinstall from fedml_databricks import DbConnection,predict 
import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
import json 
import socket 

hostname = socket.gethostname() ip_address = socket.gethostbyname(hostname) display({"Cluster Hostname": hostname, "Cluster IP Address": ip_address})​
  • 8. Step: In SAP Datasphere whitelist the IP Address
  • 9. Step: Create personal token in SAP Databricks
  • 10. Step: Create Scope
  • 11. Step: Create Secret (enter Credentials from SAP Datasphere Database User)
  • 12. Step: Establish Connection with Secret
pip install hana-ml
from hana_ml.dataframe import ConnectionContext
conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address='',
                                   port=443, 
                                   user='', 
                                   password='' 
                                  )
conn.connection.isconnected()
  • 13. Step: Connect to view 
df_remote = hana_conn.table('<yourexposedview>', schema='<yourspaceschema>')​

Congrats! You now can perform predictions based on your data in SAP Datashere. You can return the data to SAP Datasphere as HANA Table.

entry.title: Debugging in ABAP Development Tool (Part 2)
entry.content:
Introduction 

The Blog (Part 2) provides step by step guide on how to debug the report programs, classes, Function modules and Internal tables using Eclipse ADT (ABAP Development Tool). 

Part 1 link - Debugging in ABAP Development Tool (Part 1) - SAP Community
 
In this blog, we will be covering  

  1. How to set the Dynamic Breakpoints.
  2.  How to check the type of Breakpoint set. 
  3. How to skip the set Breakpoints. 
  4. How to Insert, delete and update records of Internal table. 
  5. How to Export data from the internal table. 
  6. How to Refresh the set Breakpoints. 

Dynamic Breakpoints 

Statement Breakpoint 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoints in Breakpoints tab as shown below 

Then click on Add Statement Breakpoint 

Then type READ E and then select the as shown and then click on ok  

Message Breakpoint 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoint and then click on Add Message Breakpoint 

Provide the message details and then click on ok 

We can observe the breakpoint set at message 

 

Checking the type of Breakpoint set 
Click on View menu in that click on Group by and then click on Breakpoint Types 

We can observe the type of breakpoint set 

 

Skipping the set Breakpoints 

Click on Skip All Breakpoints icon in Breakpoint table 

We can observe the skip breakpoint icon on all set breakpoints 

 

Inserting, Updating and Deleting the record of Internal table in Debugging 

Inserting the data of Internal table 

Right click on record and then click on Insert Row 

Provide the values and then click on ok 

We can observe the record is appended at the last row 

Changing values of Internal table 

Right click on record and then click on Change Value 

Change the value and then click on ok 

We can observe the updated value 

Deleting the record of Internal table 

Select the record, right click on the record and then click on Delete Selected Rows 

We can observe the selected record got deleted

 

Exporting the data of Internal table 

Right click on Internal table record and then click on Export to File 

Select the number of rows to be exported, provide the path to store the file and then click on ok 

We get the popup to open the file or close the file 

 

Refreshing the set Breakpoints 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoints in Breakpoint tab and then click on Refresh Breakpoint Activation 

 

Conclusion

Debugging internal tables in ADT offers deep visibility into runtime data, making it easier to trace logic and pinpoint issues. We can inspect table contents live, apply filters, and monitor changes using watchpoints and expressions. The structured viewer simplifies analysis of nested and dynamic data. Overall, it streamlines troubleshooting and enhances development efficiency.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 1
entry.content:
En el mundo de los sistemas de gestión empresarial, extender una aplicación o funcionalidad estándar es crucial para adaptarse a aquellas necesidades específicas de tu negocio o para darle competitividad a tu negocio con diferenciación. SAP Cloud ERP o comúnmente llamada SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, ofrece una amplia gama de opciones que le permiten a las empresas personalizar sus sistemas sin comprometer la actualización automática (upgrade) de la plataforma. En este blog y en español 🙂,  exploraremos los tipos de extensiones disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP y cómo saber cúal y cuando usarlas. Este blog es la primera parte de una serie que pretende explicar de forma sencilla las opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP.

 

In-App Extensions

¿Qué son? Las In-App Extensions permiten personalizar aplicaciones directamente dentro del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP.  Estas extensiones son ideales para pequeños ajustes y personalizaciones que no requieren un desarrollo complejo.

Para el desarrollo de extensiones In-App tenemos dos opciones:

  • Key-user Extensibility: Estas extensiones son fáciles de crear, no requieren conocimiento complejo de programación y se hacen directamente en el sistema. Puedes crear campos personalizados, extensiones de fuentes de datos e implementar descripciones para contextos empresariales específicos, adaptando así las aplicaciones predefinidas a las necesidades de tu negocio. También puedes crear vistas personalizadas de CDS (SAP Core Data Services) basadas en fuentes de datos predefinidas, combinar datos de diferentes fuentes y reorganizar los campos de las tablas según las necesidades específicas de la aplicación.
  • Developer Extensibility: Este tipo de extensiones se crean utilizando las ADT (ABAP Development Tools), requieren de conocimiento de ABAP y actualmente premiten el uso de ABAP Cloud. La extensibilidad del desarrollador permite crear proyectos de desarrollo en SAP Cloud ERP, incluyendo la creación de servicios y aplicaciones SAP Fiori personalizados con el modelo ABAP RESTful Application Programming (RAP), utilizando un subconjunto optimizado para la nube del lenguaje ABAP y APIs/objetos liberados de SAP, con acceso controlado a herramientas administrativas y con seguridad predeterminada para tablas personalizadas.

¿Cuándo usarlas?

  • Key User Extensibility: Ideal para usuarios finales que necesitan realizar ajustes menores y personalizaciones básicas sin necesidad de codificación extensiva.
  • Developer Extensibility: Necesaria para desarrolladores que requieren crear funcionalidades completamente nuevas, realizar integraciones complejas o realizar optimizaciones avanzadas, conocimiento de ABAP es necesario

Ventajas:

  • Integración: Totalmente integradas dentro del sistema, lo que asegura una actualización sin problemas.
  • Rapidez: Permiten realizar cambios rápidamente sin necesidad de salir del entorno de SAP S/4HANA.

 

Side-by-Side Extensions

¿Qué son? Las Side-by-Side Extensions se desarrollan fuera del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP utilizando el SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), pero se integran con el sistema mediante APIs liberados. Estas extensiones son ideales para necesidades más complejas que no pueden ser cubiertas por las extenciones directamente en la solucion (Key-user y Developer Extensibility).

¿Cuándo usarlas?

  • Desarrollar aplicaciones personalizadas que complementen la funcionalidad estándar de SAP Cloud ERP.
  • Integrar con sistemas de terceros o soluciones externas.
  • Crear portales de clientes o aplicaciones móviles.
  • Aprovechar las capacidades de SAP Build
  • Desarrollar extensiones usando múltiples lenguajes de programación como ABAP, Java, JavaScript o Python.

Ventajas:

  • Flexibilidad: Permiten un mayor grado de personalización y complejidad.
  • Independencia: El desarrollo se realiza fuera del sistema, lo que facilita la gestión del ciclo de vida de la aplicación y mantenimiento.
  • Integración: Utilizan APIs estándar para conectarse con SAP Cloud ERP, lo que asegura una integración segura y eficiente.

 

Conclusión

Las opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, son diversas, permiten adaptar la solución a las necesidades específicas de cada negocio, principalmente teniendo como ventaja, que no comprometen la estabilidad ni la capacidad de actualización del sistema. Desde In-App Extensions para cambios rápidos y sencillos, hasta Side-by-Side Extensions para necesidades más complejas y Custom Apps para soluciones altamente personalizadas, cada tipo de extensión tiene su propósito y ventajas.

Espero que esta guía te haya proporcionado una comprensión clara de las opciones de extensibilidad disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP.

¡No dudes en explorar más para descubrir cómo estas herramientas pueden ayudar a tu empresa a alcanzar nuevos niveles de eficiencia y personalización!

 

Links Relevantes:

SAP Community: La comunidad de SAP es un excelente lugar para encontrar blogs, tutoriales y discusiones sobre extensibilidad.

    • SAP Community

Documentación Oficial de SAP: La documentación oficial proporciona una guía detallada sobre cómo extender SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

    • SAP S/4HANA Cloud - Help Portal

SAP Extensibility Explorer

    • SAP Extensibility Explorer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

SAP API Business Hub: Aquí puedes encontrar APIs, eventos y otros servicios que te permiten extender tus aplicaciones SAP.

    • SAP API Business Hub - S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): Plataforma en la nube que incluye varios servicios para la extensibilidad.

    • SAP BTP

SAP Web IDE: Herramienta de desarrollo en la nube que facilita la extensibilidad de SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

    • SAP Web IDE

SAP Cloud SDK: Kit de desarrollo de software que facilita la integración y ampliación de soluciones SAP.

    • SAP Cloud SDK

 

📽¡Vea las repeticiones de nuestra serie de lanzamiento anticipado de SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502!  

Del 21 al 25 de julio, organizamos una serie de 21 interesantes sesiones en vivo para destacar las emocionantes innovaciones que incluye la versión 2508 de SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. ¿Te perdiste las sesiones en vivo? ¡Te ayudamos! Aprovecha la serie completa o elige las sesiones que más te interesen. Encontrarás la grabación y la presentación sobre Portafolio Empresarial y Gestión de Proyectos, además de otros 20 temas de interés. No te pierdas esta oportunidad y mírala las sesiones, donde y cuando quieras.
